TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , ORG at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

Until DATE the applicant was the managing director of ORG , a company incorporated under NORP law . The company ran a mail - order business selling food supplements designed to aid weight loss . Among these were a liquid product called PERSON CARDINAL and effervescent tablets called LANGUAGE - GPE . The applicant indicated that these had been purchased from “ a laboratory with the normal accreditation for such products ” , based in GPE .

The applicant added that the products in question had previously been marketed in GPE and that “ for this reason , ORG , ORG and the Environment had , in accordance with the procedure in place in the country , authorised [ their ] release onto the market after verification of [ their ] conformity as a nutrient[s ] within the meaning of Community legislation and in particular Directive No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EC of DATE ” . In that connection he provided , in particular , a document dated DATE , issued by ORG , acknowledging receipt of a “ notification file ” and assigning a “ plant number ” to GPE .

Advertising carried out for the marketing of these products in GPE attracted the attention of ORG , ORG , which consequently conducted a number of investigations ( in DATE and DATE ) . Noting that the Sveltys - GPE tablets contained sodium benzoate , they contacted the person who had taken over from the applicant as managing director of DATE who passed them the above - mentioned document dated DATE and then contacted ORG in GPE . The latter responded in the following terms in a letter dated DATE :

“ ... Further to your letter dated DATE relating to non - compliance of the food supplement L[y]ghtyss with Directive No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on food additives other than colours and sweeteners ( unauthorised presence of sodium benzoate in a solid food supplement ) ... , we have taken the necessary measures to compel the company ORG that markets this product in GPE to comply with the directive within DATE . If the company fails to do so within the period we have allowed , we shall withdraw its notification number .... We thank you for this information ... ”

The applicant and the person who had succeeded him as managing director of the company ORG and the company itself were prosecuted in the criminal courts . They were charged with , inter alia , false advertising , firstly regarding the composition , essential qualities , content of active ingredients , mode of manufacture , properties and expected effects of food supplements with alleged slimming qualities , and secondly by featuring fictitious studies by researchers on the identity , qualifications or skills of the retailers of these products . They were also prosecuted for having ( during DATE and until DATE ) displayed , marketed or sold foodstuffs to be used for human consumption which they knew to be adulterated , tainted or toxic , by marketing food supplements containing sodium benzoate ( ORG tablets ) , namely , an unauthorised product in non - liquid food supplements .

By a decision of DATE , ORG found the defendants guilty on those counts . It sentenced the applicant to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment and a fine of QUANTITY ( ORG ) ; the other defendants were sentenced to fines of LAW and LAW respectively .
ORG upheld ORG ruling on these points . Its judgment , delivered on DATE , highlights the following points in particular :

“ ... the Order of DATE [ which transposes into NORP law several ORG directives on food additives , including Directive No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EC of DATE ] , provides that ‘ maximum levels indicated in GPE , PERSON and V refer to foodstuffs as marketed , unless otherwise stated ; sodium benzoate ( preservative E CARDINAL ) appears in GPE of this Order , which is permitted in food supplements up to a level of QUANTITY , but only in liquid food supplements .
The PERSON - Lightyss tablets were sold in solid form , so it is immaterial whether they were effervescent or intended to be ingested in liquid form .

Once ORG had acknowledged that the presence of sodium benzoate in solid tablets was such as to cause it to revise its previous position , the defendants could no longer rely on an authorisation they had obtained from the NORP authorities ; in any event , a decision taken by the authorities contrary to Community law does not create rights and can not result in an acquittal of the defendants on these charges ... ’
By a judgment of DATE , ORG dismissed an appeal lodged by the convicted parties , rejecting the ground of appeal based , inter alia , on LAW as follows :

“ It is apparent from the judgment appealed against and the documents in the proceedings that the company ORG and its CARDINAL successive managing directors ... were prosecuted in the criminal court on a charge of selling and releasing for sale adulterated food products on the grounds that in DATE and DATE theysold food supplements in the form of effervescent tablets , called PERSON and PERSON , containing an illegal additive : sodium benzoate ;

In finding the defendants guilty of the offence , ORG held that the tablets were released for sale in solid form and that , consequently , the use of sodium benzoate was not permitted , since Directive No . CARDINAL of DATE , transposed into national law by the ministerial order of DATE , restricts the use of this preservative to liquid food supplements ;

On these grounds alone , and since at the material time sodium benzoate could not be incorporated , either in GPE or GPE , into solid food supplements , ORG justified its decision with regard to the legal and LAW provisions relied on ;
Article L. CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the Consumer Code is worded as follows :
“ Anyone who
CARDINAL . adulterates foodstuffs for human or animal consumption , medicines , drinks , or agricultural or natural products intended for sale ;
CARDINAL . displays , markets or sells foodstuffs for human or animal consumption , drinks , or agricultural or natural products which they know to be adulterated , tainted or toxic
shall be liable to the penalties provided for in LAW

The adulteration of a product may result from the addition of a substance deemed illegal under the applicable law ( PERSON . PERSON . , DATE , No . CARDINAL ) or , more generally , from “ recourse to unlawful processing that fails to comply with the regulations in place , with the effect of altering the substance ” ( GPE . PERSON . , DATE , No . CARDINAL ) .

Directive No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EC of ORG and ORG on food additives other than colours and sweeteners ” ( ORG L CARDINAL of DATE , p.CARDINAL ) stipulates that the additives listed in GPE and PERSON “ may only be used in the foodstuffs referred to in [ the said ] PERSON and under the conditions specified therein ” ( LAW , paragraph CARDINAL of the Directive ) . Sodium benzoate appears in GPE ( Part A ) . Unlike “ liquid ” food supplements , “ solid ” food supplements are not mentioned in the list of foodstuffs for which they can be used . This Directive was transposed into NORP law by the Order of CARDINAL October CARDINAL “ on additives usable in the manufacture of foodstuffs intended for human consumption ” ( ORG No . CARDINAL of DATE , p. DATE ) .
